item.title: The Ubiquitous Cloud of 2012
item.description: The year 2012 brings a shift in the business landscape, not towards a downturn, but rather a move towards cloud computing. This change benefits businesses facing uncertainty by offering flexibility and adaptability. Instead of struggling to predict the future, businesses can embrace the cloud and adjust their strategies as needed. The current business environment is already in flux. While some businesses are stagnant, others experience constant change. This unpredictability leaves many longing for a more stable past.

item.title: Computing In The Cloud
item.description: The term “cloud computing” has become ubiquitous, but what does it entail and what are its advantages over traditional data centers? Initially, cloud computing provided access to a network of computers for tasks that exceeded the capabilities of individual resources. A prime example is the SETI@Home program, which harnesses the idle processing power of countless personal computers connected through the internet to analyze radio telescope data in search of extraterrestrial life.

item.title: How The Cloud Provides Virtualization For The SMB
item.description: Virtualization has been a popular topic for large businesses for a while. It allows them to maximize their existing resources, turning one server into multiple virtual ones and distributing heavy workloads across platforms. But can smaller businesses also benefit from virtualization? The answer is a resounding yes, thanks to the cloud. The cloud’s power lies in virtualization, enabling it to function as a massive data center accessible to numerous users. By efficiently utilizing virtualization, cloud providers can create an illusion of infinite resources, making each user feel like the sole user.

item.title: SMB Cloud Computing Portfolio
item.description: While large companies have widely adopted cloud computing, small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) may wonder about its relevance for them. Broadview Networks offers a range of cloud services ideal for such businesses. Already a prominent communications provider in the Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic US, Broadview provides various connectivity options, including T1 lines, Ethernet, fiber optic connections, and traditional phone lines. What distinguishes Broadview is its ability to provide both cloud services and the reliable connectivity these services require, unlike many cloud providers that only offer the infrastructure.
